courses.name: Culture and the Media in Canada

cmCourseInfo.description: An exploration of the encounter between culture and mass communication in Canadian society. The course considers the role of major cultural institutions such as the CBC, the NFB, and their granting bodies. The emergence of new media and its relationship to mass media is also addressed.
cmCourseInfo.title: Culture and the Media in Canada

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, synchronous course.
It will meet from 2-4 on Mondays and Wednesdays.
There will an emphasis on in-class discussion.
Notes will also be posted online after each class describing what was discussed.
Students need zoom.us and the ability to use it.

cmCourseInfo.description: An interdisciplinary course that interrogates the constitution of blackness in Canada. Students will study race and ethnic relations, alongside other identity formations such as class, gender and sexuality. Topics to be addressed include media, education, law, immigration and mobility, urbanism, work, political representation and the arts.
cmCourseInfo.title: Black Canadian Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, synchronous course.
It will meet from 10am-1pm on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
There will an emphasis on in-class discussion.
Notes will also be posted online after each class describing what was discussed.
Students need zoom.us and the ability to use it.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will introduce students to quantitative research tools developed through the Digital Humanities. Students will learn to use online text analytics tools in order to understand how quantitative methods can support critical academic research of the study of Canada. Quantitative digital analysis will be applied to a wide range of Canadian digital academic archives and community hubs.
cmCourseInfo.title: Digital Media, Digital Makers

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This is an online, synchronous course.
It will meet from 10am-12pm on Mondays and Wednesdays.
There will an emphasis on online full/ small group discussion via BB Collaborate as the full class group and small (4 students) peer group activities.
Classes will be recorded to archive for review after class, including: Lecture/ Q & A / small group BB Collaborate group work.
Notes & exercises will also be posted online before each class outlining what will be discussed and activities that can be done ahead of time, or in-class during the 3 hour window. The latter is designed so that you will not have to be online for the full 3 hours.
A schedule of approximate synchronous / online time varied with solo online activities will be available by the start of class.
We will likely work with BB Collaborate for the online lecture.
Students may need zoom.us, and some familiarity as to how to use it.
